Hey Grace. I'm an Chinese from Malaysia and I too was very surprised by the 
new trailers coming out. I was under the impression this was gonna be a 
very Asian film mainly because on the title card for all the posters and 
trailers, there are those Japanese words. I'm also quite concerned with 
this race changing focus by Hollywood. I understand why it is done since 
Hollywood is mainly for America while Asian countries have our own film 
industries but I really saw an opportunity for them to venture out.
I understand using Brian Cranston at the start of the film to get Western 
audiences connected, but I really hope they focus more on a mixed race cast 
during the main length of the movie.
I am not a Godzilla fan but I know a few people who are and are not usually 
into watching films in english. Watching the first trailer, they seemed 
really excited about it but that excitement is seeming to die down, just 
like yours. It's a real shame because their Godzilla has always been a 
Japanese Kaiju and I can see the sadness in their eyes when they talk about 
that. They will still watch the movie and I'm sure they'll enjoy the fights 
and action but I don't think they'll be enjoying anything more than that.
I, as someone who grew up on english language films, am not as affected but 
I can see how one would be unhappy with it. It feels very personal to have 
a racial change in a movie.
And as a Malaysian, being so close to Indonesia, it sucks that they are 
remaking the Raid.﻿

As someone who loathes Grace's obsession with race on this channel, I must 
say that I really agree with her on this one. She has a way of putting it 
that is like being forced  to listen to a freshman orientation session on 
diversity, but her central point is solid. Part of the charm and legendary 
status of Godzilla is its Japanese origin. Without that, it really isn't 
Godzilla -- period. At least the first movie should really be focused in 
Japan and yes, with lots and lots of Asian actors. 
I realize that it is difficult to listen to her arguments as she blames the 
Tonight Show while ignoring the much larger problem of The Daily Show. And 
to hear her talk about Obama as if his election is a good thing is like 
nails on a chalkboard to most people, of course (don't hate -- look at the 
polls). She means it simply because he is part black, naturally, and the 
fact that he is a disaster is irrelevant to this way of thinking. And her 
frequent approval of China's dictates toward American films reminds people 
of the other times that the liberals of Hollywood cooperated with strong 
socialist parties like the Nazis. But, again, this is just how liberals 
think and for reasons that I am unclear on, Grace has decided to turn this 
channel into a sort of a "diversity" professor's look at the movies. She's 
very talented and appears to really work hard to put out a good product, so 
It's a bit of a puzzle why she wants it this way, but, hey, it is her show 
-- she can do what she wants.
But, in this case it is best to ignore all of that and say that when she is 
right, she is right and on Godzilla she is indeed right!  ﻿

Let me start off by saying it takes gall to lecture real fans of the 
Godzilla franchise about maintaining the culture and integrity of the 
original toho films. I'm a huge fan of this franchise and have a lot of 
nostalgia regarding it. As if you can say the same. Also, race and culture 
are not one in the same. Just because Hawaiians are technically Asian, 
doesn't mean they're linked to the Japanese culture Godzilla originated 
from. JAPANESE! Not just Asian. Whom by the way don't need you to defend 
their honor. From what I've seen from overall media, this movie is chalked 
full of potential nostalgia and nods to the original films. Not to mention 
THAT THE JAPANESE ORIGINS ARE EXPLAINED AND/OR IMPLIED BY EVEN THE TRAILER 
ALONE unlike the examples you gave which supposedly had no reference. Which 
by the way ALL of your arguments were full of holes. Including the Johnny 
storm bullshit. People were mad because they changed something that 
everyone was familiar with and shredded up years worth nostalgia and, not 
to mention, no one was asking for the change. Why didn't they make a brand 
new black hero instead of reforming a character that fans have come to know 
and love. Also, Johnny storm was a re-occurring character with history. 
These characters are newly introduced and therefore people care less. 
People tend to like things that are familiar. This isn't a racist thing. 
For example I watched the justice league cartoon when I was young. My first 
account with the green lantern was the black version. Even today, my 
favorite version is the BLACK justice league version. And I'm a white guy. 
Anyway, I could go on forever completely picking your arguments apart but 
I'm literally getting a frustration headache. Just please, PLEASE stop 
reviewing this movie. Your enraging too many people, this can't be 
productive. And also, try being a little less pretentious on a subject 
(Godzilla) that you know very little about. And yes commenters will tear 
you apart. WELCOME TO THE INTERNET! This is what you signed up for. We're a 
bunch of animals get used to it. Regardless of whether you'll read this or 
if this even effected your opinion, I got to vent and that felt good

BUTTFUCK.... That is all.﻿

Hi Grace, interesting discussion in your review. Though I am still abundant 
with excitement for this film, you do raise an interesting discussion. I 
can see there are others in agreement with you despite some of the negative 
replies it generated. 

However interesting point I'd like to bring up-once in a documentary by BBC 
for godzilla made around 1998, there is a point where they talk about the 
American film in 1998 and a former director of the franchise,Jun Fukuda, 
said how every nation could possibly have their own international Godzilla 
with different takes on that story, Japanese godzilla, American godzilla, 
maybe even a British Godzilla someday. (Interesting that this is billed as 
an American godzilla when a lot of British are involved behind the camera) 

Toho exported the rights back in 1994 with guidelines, the jan deBont 
version was canceled by Tristar but had a godzilla that was true to the 
spirit of the character. It however took place in America primarily. The 
film was never made due to budget, then the Roland Emmerich version was 
made and he went forth and made a version that didn't even follow toho's 
guidelines but they were so far invested they couldn't back out. 

This seems to have a little more cooperation from toho with legendary and 
seems to be meeting the guidelines with a timely message of Mother Nature 
striking back due to man's ambitions, a prevalent theme in the early films. 
Yes it's a shame that there couldn't be more international characters in 
the leads despite the global scale this seems to be promoting, but I am 
with the group that agrees that we want a well made film, and while you 
were right in raising the issue and politics going on in the industry, a 
lot more action needs to be taken for any change to be made. Still, great 
for sticking to your convictions and I'll still watch this movie and you 
and am interested in your final review when the film makes landfall. 

Take care :) ﻿

To be honest, I'm really surprised by the amount of racial discussion (in 
terms of characters for this film). We may be used to the old Godzilla 
films where he's terrorizing Japan and the Japanese people, but so what if 
the location focus of THIS new film happens elsewhere than Japan? Is that 
really going to matter AT ALL in terms of whether a good film was crafted 
with lots of action, incredible visual effects, and - just maybe - 
well-developed characters? No, it won't. So whether it happens in Japan, 
the U.S., or Mongolia.....I could care less. Also, even if the Japanese 
characters are scientists or in some other position of importance where 
they can contribute to the events going on in the film, they're not being 
mistreated or negatively stereotyped. Ken Watanabe, I suspect, has an 
important part in the film.....and so what if he's a scientist, he's a man 
of respect. So let's lay off the talk of racism and Hollywood sterotypes, 
these are pieces of fiction and fantasy....NOT REAL LIFE. ﻿

What the hell are you raving about it not being accurate? Accurate to what? 
When someone says that a film's characters are not being accurate to the 
source material, I assume they mean the original film's actual characters. 

This is a reboot. It's essentially a complete redo of the original story, 
while still retaining some elements from it. 

There are no characters from the original in this film. There is no Ogata, 
there is no Emiko(and I have to assume you have no idea whom I'm talking 
about, so I'll stop.). This film will have its own cast of original 
characters. Therefore, there is no way for it to be "accurate" to the 
original film's characters or even setting, since it's something that is 
set apart from the original.

Have I made myself clear? Your "argument" about this film not being 
"faithful" has just been debunked. ﻿

Okay, I would like to point out that racism is still very common in 
Hollywood. Hollywood thinks that non-white actors (especially Asians) are 
not "profitable" enough, and that movies need whiteactors in order to make 
money.

So they often reject directors who want to make movies about non-white 
actors, because Hollywood assumes that their movies won't be successful.

It's like with Wong Fu Productions (popular YouTube Channel). They were 
going to make a movie in Hollywood, and they wanted their main characters 
to be Asian. But Hollywood told them that Asians arent profitable enough, 
and that movies need to be about white people in order to make money. They 
kept trying to persuade them to chose white actors instead, and when they 
didn't, Hollywood cancelled their movie.

Or like with Tokyo Drift. The director had to fight in order to have 
colorblind auditions for his main character. He wanted to chose an Asian 
actor, but the studio was persistent on having a white actor. (and that's 
what they ended up having).

Or with Mako, he wanted to make a TV show with an Asian protagonist, but 
Hollywood executives told him that audiences would shut off the TV if they 
seen an Asian hero. So the rejected his pitch.

I'm just saying. Actors should be chosen based on talent, but it's 100% 
like that in Hollywood. Talented Asian actors are often turned down... this 
doesn't mean Godzilla is racist for having a mostly white cast, it just 
means that Hollywood is a fucked up place which is very judgemental to 
actors who are "minorities" (like non-white people, women, LGBTQ+, disabled 
people, etc).

I think the simple point I want to get across as a Godzilla fan is this. 
Race/location is simply not an important thing I care about when it comes 
to seeing the franchise being rebooted. What I care about is seeing the 
creators of the film being true to the monster itself, something the 1998 
film failed to do, and for the movie to harken back to the original movie's 
tone, both of which this new movie seems to be doing. In the end, 'staying 
true to the franchise' for a lot of us means staying true to the monster 
more than anything having to do with the human characters involved. I kind 
of feel like you want this movie to be something more Grace, while a lot of 
us just want a good movie, that can help reinvigorate the genre, seeing as 
how Pacific Rim failed to really make a splash last year. The difference 
for this movie and the many other examples you gave as to why many of us 
find it okay to white-wash this movie, while we may find it less okay for 
others comes down to this actually. Many of those movies are part of genres 
that are thriving and can afford to take chances. Godzilla is part of a 
long dead genre that really can't afford to, if it wants to succeed.﻿

as they were in the Japanese films but the core characteristics remain.

in the right hands and any changes made, such as making Godzilla less 
Asian, are probably for the better. ﻿

One of them dies, the other is traumatized, and now, a Japanese scientist- 
yes stoic and maybe stereotypical- is coming in to FIX THE PROBLEM.
 Think of it this way: For so long, for 60 years, Godzilla has been in 
Japan, the nation that experienced nuclear attacks. Now, he's attacking the 
country that built the atom bomb, the United States. After all, the film is 
more focused on man's arrogance towards nature. Who is more responsible for 
that sin? The victims of the atomic bomb, or the creators? You can call 
this casting objective racism all you want. I call it subjective national 
karma. It's horror, and horror loves karma.
 The United States of America has one of the most powerful armed forces of 
all time. US army vs. King of the Monsters. That's a clash I've been 
wanting to see for a long time. So no, this movie's climax shouldn't be in 
Japan, and thankfully that's the case.
 One more thing, Gareth Edwards didn't pick Bryan Cranston for Breaking 
Bad, he picked him for Malcom in the Middle. He said he played a good 
father figure. If you don't call that risk-taking, I don't know what is.
 In conclusion- this Godzilla just may be much more authentic than you 
think.

Hey Grace, I understand some of your points and as an African American I 
would also like to see more diversity in American films. However I have 
some points of contention.

The Godzilla franchise has existed for around 60 years now and consists of 
28 films with a majority Japanese cast. I have doubts that after over half 
a century of relevance that this single American interpretation, which is 
supported by Toho Studios, is enough to "rob Godzilla of its cultural 
importance." If the Roland Emmerich  version wasn't able to do so I really 
don't think this version will.

Also, being an American interpretation, studios would seek out actors that 
American audiences are more familiar with, hence the casting of actors like 
Bryan Cranston. We do not know how big of a role Bryan Cranston will play 
in the film but they are pushing his image because he is the most popular 
actor in the movie.

I don't think they are being disrespectful to the source material, they are 
just presenting their take on it. I wouldn't say that Turkish Rambo(1986) 
is robbing Rambo of its cultural importance because it only features 
Turkish actors and has no American actors. They are just presenting a 
Turkish interpretation of it.

Although I do understand how you feel about the casting decisions, I think 
we should also focus on other aspects of the movie besides the race of the 
actors. There are probably a lot of people who worked hard to put this 
movie together that had absolutely nothing to do with the casting decisions 
and it's sad to see their efforts being ignored because we do not feel 
there are enough Asian actors in the movie.﻿

You also said something about the characters in this Godzilla film being

No, I agree totally that it's not racebaiting to discuss the shutout of 
Asian actors and actresses in Hollywood, but for Godzilla specifically, I 
think it is. To simply say this is whitewashed and doesn't pay homage to

Gareth Edwards and his team, Edwards who of which are big Godzilla fans. 
WB/Legendary are using Godzilla, the pop icon not specific human 
characters, she mentioned ordinary men in extraordinary situations but 
think we can qualify Watanabe as an ordinary man. I don't to me it just 
felt she was making too much of it as far as Godzilla the film was 
concerned specifically, I always looked at Godzilla as a sort of global 
Icon that everybody could enjoy and everyone knew. Godzilla is essentially 
Japanese and this re-imagining/remake is homage to his legacy.

As for the rest of Hollywood... I just don't understand them, I don't know 
why they can't see past ethnicity, there are great actors in the east, they 
don't want to take a chance on an Asian actor but they want to take the 
work itself. To a degree I can understand adapting a work from Japan to

It would be ignorant if she judged the quality of the film based on the 
race of the actors.
However, it's not "racebaiting" to talk about race in Hollywood at all. 
Hollywood itself is very focused on race.... they do not like hiring non 
white actors (especially if they are Asian) in lead roles, because they 
think that movies need white lead actors in order to be successful. They 
think that American audiences need white people in movies, in order for 
them to have people to relate to.. 

I keep saying this, but again, it's like Wong Fu Productions. They wanted 
to make a movie with an Asian main character, but Hollywood producers told 
them that Asians are not profitable enough and that movies need white 
characters in order to be successful. Or with Mako, who wanted to make a TV 
show starring an Asian protagonist, but Hollywood turned him down because 
they said that "[american] audiences would shut off the TV if they seen an 
Asian hero."
Are they correct? I don't know. I haven't seen a successful American film 
that has had an entirely Asian cast before (unless you count Mulan?), I 
don't know if they are correct in saying that American audiences are 
disinterested in Asian characters. But I would like to see more diversity 
on TV anyhow.

Movies SHOULDN'T be judged on the color of the characters skin. But it 
should be known that Hollywood judges actors by their race. They're less 
likely to hire non-white actors (especially Asians) for lead roles, because 
they say that Asian actors make American/western audiences disinterested. 
And that Americans can't "relate" to Asian characters as well as white 
characters.

Like with "21," the director didn't consider any Asian actors (even though 
all the people in the original story were Asian) because they said that 
there are no "bankable" Asian actors, and that they wanted their movie to 
make money.

Or with Wong Fu Productions, who wanted to make a movie starring a lead 
Asian-American actor. But Hollywood producers kept trying to persuade them 
to chose white actors instead, because they said that Asians aren't 
"profitable" enough and that movies about white people make more money. So 
they cancelled production on the movie when WFP didn't chose white actors 
instead.

Or with Mako, who wanted to make an American TV show with an Asian-American 
lead actor, but Hollywood executives rejected him because they said that 
"audiences would shut off the TV if they seen an Asian hero."

OR with Justin Lin, who wanted to hire an Asian lead actor for the "Tokyo 
Drift" movie but had to fight with Hollywood studios in order to have a 
colorblind casting session for the main characters. Because they studio was 
uncomfortable with hiring an Asian lead actor, as they said that the movie 
needed a caucasian lead actor.

So while I don't think it's okay to hate on Godzilla, it should be known 
that moviemaking is not just an "art." It's about making money, too. And 
those who want to make movies about non-white people have to struggle to 
get their movies greenlight, or to hire Asian lead actors.

be satisfactorily reverent to the source material. To me this just sounds 
like you're someone who suffers from white guilt and you're using Godzilla 
of all things to climb the ol' soap box. And if you really want your 
Godzilla movie to have an Asian-centric feel, watch one of the other 28 
movies Toho made over a 50 year span. I get this feeling you haven't seen 
any of them. Now as a longtime fan of Godzilla and of Japanese culture in 
general, I can say I am more than completely satisfied with the 
appreciation the filmmakers have for the original character. Ken Watanabe's 
character is not in fact your stereotypical "Asian guy is a scientist" 
character. His name, Dr. Serizawa, is taken directly from the most pivotal 
character from the original 1954 movie, the man who creates the weapon that 
ultimately kills the first Godzilla. Another point to reference is that in 
the first official trailer Serizawa says that in 1954 they tried to kill 
Godzilla with nuclear bombs, disguised as test bombings. 1954 is the year 
of the first movie's release in Japan. And in what I think is the biggest 
show of reverence and respect for the original, the star of 1954's Gojira, 
Akira Takarada, will have some kind of cameo role in the movie, possibly in 
the flashbacks to 1954. So there you go, three things the filmmakers did 
that they didn't need to in order to show respect to the source material of 
this AMERICAN reboot. I'm saddened to say that some people will probably 
accuse this movie of being "racist" because it doesn't "have enough Asian 
people" in it or their role "isn't big enough", and to them I'll say Ken 
Watanabe has second billing behind Aaron Taylor-Johnson. And if someone 
calls me racist or insensitive because of what I've said, then that's just 
pathetic.﻿

As with most things "Hawaii" and "Hawaiian" I often feel the need to 
educate. I will offer insight and maybe perspective, and I offer it without 
malice or ill intent. Firstly, yes Hawaii has a very large Asian 
populations. The most visible being the Japanese, the second would be the 
Filipino's(oes), the third would be the Chinese. There are also large 
populations of Okinawans and Koreans. Native Hawaiians however are not 
"Asian" we are part of the Polynesian race of peoples. We are related to 
the Tahitians, Samoans and the Maori of New Zealand. These are just few of 
the Polynesian people there are many others too numerous to list. People 
often do not know that the term "Native Hawaiian" when applied to 
Non-Hawaiians is highly offensive to us. For instance people often use the 
"Term" "Native" to denote people being from somewhere. People will often 
say something along the lines "I am a New york native" or "I am a 
california native. While these terms apply in other places, they do not 
apply when refering to "Hawaiian Natives" Why? because in our case it 
refers to a specific race of people. So please anyone refering to a "Native 
Hawaiian" in the future please undserstand that unless that person self 
indentifies as a "Native Hawaiian" it is inappropriate and highly 
contentious to refer to them so. We often run into people who don't know 
how to address our race and sometimes that can lead to issues. Any 
Non-Hawaiian who is  from Hawaii is called a "Local". One however does not 
call a "Native Hawaiian" a "Local" it is an insult of the highest order. If 
one cannot determin if you are addressing a "Native" or a "Local" just ask. 
The term "Hapa" has been envogue" the past few years. It's a Hawaiian word 
that means mixed blood. More often it means in today's vernacular someone 
who is half white and some other racial admixture (Hapa Haole= Half White). 
I am not saying that any statements made during the discussion were right 
or wrong, I am just educating. Please accept it in the manner it was given. 
Mahalo Nui and Aloha to All.﻿

All kidding aside, the original 1954 Godzilla was controversial for its 
time.  Godzilla symbolizes  what happens when you "nuclear holocaust" a 
city, namely Hiroshima on August 6, 1945, and Nagasaki on August 9. 
Godzilla is "natures revenge" for creating the atom bomb.
 
"In 1956 TransWorld Releasing Corp. released an edited version of the film 
theatrically in the United States titled Godzilla, King of the Monsters!. 
This version featured newly shot scenes of Hollywood actor Raymond Burr 
spliced into the original Japanese footage."  This is the version I watched 
as a kid. I didn't realize at the time why they edited Raymond Burr into 
the movie. I do now, talk about controversy.
 
The reason why this Godzilla doesn't take place entirely in Japan is 
because of what  Kyohei Yamane-hakase explains in the original 1954 movie.  
"I can't believe that Godzilla was the only surviving member of its 
species... But if we continue conducting nuclear tests, it's possible that 
another Godzilla might appear somewhere in the world again."

In the 2014 previews we see Las Vegas, NV, and something huge crashed 
through Las Vegas Blvd. Back in 1951 the United States started testing of 
nuclear devices at Nye County, Nevada, 65  miles northwest of the city of 
Las Vegas.  It would be cool if another creature or several evolves from 
this and other hot-spots globally. I think the writes did their research.. 
at least I hope so.﻿

Some stats to backup Grace's point:
-The largest Japanese population in the US are located in 
California(428,014) and Hawaii(312,292).
-The city with the most Japanese people in the US is Honolulu with 86,612. 
That's 23% of the population.
-There are 1,005,823 Asian Americans living in San Francisco. That is 23.2% 
of the population
These numbers are based on the 2010 basis. Going by those demographics, a 
realistic representation would mean that 1/4 of the cast should probably be 
of Asian. That is obviously not the case.

And while, it's true that this does not speak to the quality of the film 
itself(I don't think Grace was arguing that anyways), it doesn't mean that 
it's not important. It is significant on a social and cultural level.﻿

Hey I'm all about civility, so don't take this as an attack lol. Firstly, 
let it be known that I have no problems with Johnny Storm being black in 
the new F4 movie. As for Akira, so long as the plot's right and the acting 
is good, again, I don't care about race. Haven't seen the other films 
you've mentioned.

Now, you have to understand that Edwards kept repeatedly going back to Toho 
going "Is this okay? Is this good?", and if they told him no he would scrap 
those ideas. Toho loves him so much for his co-operation that they 
contacted Akira Takarada and sent him to visit to the set! He played Ogata 
in the original film. Just google Akira Takarada on the set of Godzilla. 
Toho's involvement has been huge here and it wasn't a case of just selling 
away the rights. Gareth Edwards himself is a huge fan and his favorite 
Godzilla film is Godzilla vs. The Smog Monster/Hedorah.

Then you're arguing that he's not staying faithful to the source material 
and I have to disagree. He's a creature given super powers brought on by 
nuclear testing in the pacific, and as we can definitely tell, it's not an 
Iguana so I'm willing to bet it's the Godzillasaurus.

Edwards has also said that he wants this movie to be grim. The effect it 
would have on families and loved ones, and he's taking care so that you'll 
actually care about the characters. "Because if somebody you don't know 
just gets stomped on, then what do you care? You don't". It reminds me of 
the Japanese release of the original film, where a daughter asks her mother 
while Godzilla attacks "Are we going to be with Daddy now?". That's the 
sort of emotion this movie is going for. The feeling of loss, grieving, 
while tackling the inherent nuclear theme that's ever-present. The 98 film 
made no such attempts.

You also have to realize that the original film was just as heavily focused 
on the military as this film.

Toho's involvement in this is much deeper than you previously thought, to 
the point where it might as well be a full Toho production.

And finally I'll point out the timer you see towards the end of this 
trailer. We had another timed device in the Godzilla franchise, and it was 
called the Oxygen Destroyer, developed by Dr. Serizawa. I'm pretty sure 
that's where they're going with Ken here.

And the fact that Toho is all giddy for the Japanese release themselves.

I agree with your thoughts on the importance of representation, cast 
diversity, and Japanese culture. After all, the original film, Gojira, was 
a Japanese response to atomic bombings and the proliferation of nuclear 
weaponry; Godzilla himself is nuclear apocalypse personified, and thus far, 
Japan is the only country to have been attacked by nuclear weapons (fingers 
crossed that it stays that way).

That said, I have quibble: wouldn't it be a tad pretentious for an American 
company and an American director to make a film that takes place in Japan? 
As an American production, it makes more sense to me for this film to take 
place in America. Recall what happened with "V for Vendetta:" many critics 
responded that this film was projecting American anxieties on to Great 
Britain.

In addition, the 2014 Godzilla film reflects different anxieties than 
Gojira did. The recent trailers imply a government conspiracy, something 
that is very topical amongst American audiences, and Ken Watanabe's 
character seems to suggest that Godzilla represents the wrath of nature, 
which reflects anxiety about climate change.

It's an American production that exists within a different cultural 
context; I'm inclined to cut it some slack.﻿

Well yeah, whenever a "racially diverse" movie flops, Hollywood blames it 
on the skin color of the actors, and becomes even more scared to make 
movies abuot non-white people. Which is wrong, considering that movies 
should be judged on their poor directing, and not because the main 
character is black or something.

It's like with "Red Tails," Hollywood refused to fund it because the 
director (George Lucas) wanted an entirely black cast. They told him that 
black people aren't marketable enough. So Lucas had to use money out of his 
own pocket ($58m) to cover production costs on the film. 
The movie failed due to bad marketing and directing, and instead of 
Hollywood blaming it on Lucas, they blamed in on the fact that all the 
actors were black (and to this day are scared to make high budget films 
with entirely black casts).

And it seems like they don't even want to test to see if movies about Asian 
actors will be successful. Everytime I hear about a movie project that was 
supposed to have a predominantly Asian cast, I notice that the director 
either says that it's a bitch to get funding for movies about minorities, 
or that their movie was cancelled because they wanted an Asian lead actor 
(like Wong Fu Production's movie, whose movie was cancelled because 
Hollywood producers told them that movies need white actors to be 
successful).

So yeah, I want to see GOOD racially diverse films that are successful at 
the box office, so that Hollywood will be less scared to greenlight movies 
with actors who are not white. I always wanted to get into filmmaking, I 
want to be able to chose what lead actors I want because I think they are 
talented (regardless of race), not what actors are considered "profitable" 
because of race.
Like if I want to make a movie about a samurai, I wouldn't want to be 
forced to chose a white actor just to pander to American audiences.

But maybe something like that won't happen until the point where America is 
so diverse that we can't really distinguish race anymore.

"Hispanic" doesn't mean non-white. A lot of Hispanics are white, because 
Spain itself is in Europe. That being said, racism in Hollywood is a legit 
discussion because it still happens. "Godzilla" isn't an inherently racist 
movie for not having an Asian cast, what's racist is the fact that 
Hollywood refuses to greenlight movies that have entirely Asian casts.
Example being "Better Luck Tomorrow," a crime/drama film that Hollywood 
intitially refused to greenlight, unless the directors chose a white cast 
(instead of his desired Asian cast). But the director was insistent on 
having his all-Asian cast, so he was given a small budget of $250,000 
(which would've been bigger had his cast been white).

Or with Wong Fu Productions, who wanted to make a movie with an Asian 
protagonist, but Hollywood producers tried to persuade them into using 
white actors instead because they said that "Asians aren't profitable 
enough" and that movies about white people make more money. And then 
Hollywood cancelled the movie when the directors got into a dispute about 
it.

OR with Mako, who wanted to make a TV show starring an Asian protagonist, 
but Hollywood executives rejected him saying that "[American] audiences 
would shut off the TV if they seen an Asian hero."

Talking about racism towards Asians isn't "reverse racism" towards white 
people ("reverse racism" is a ridiculous term anyway). Saying something 
like "all white people are racist" IS racism towards white, acknowledging 
the fact that other races occasionally face discrimination at the hands of 
white people is NOT racism towards white people.

the 2014 movie should have a greater significance on the Japanese culture.

I think the beauty of having the film take place in Japan and America 
highlights the point that not a single country is safe from total 
annihilation. You think that they should replace Bryan Cranston and 
Juliette Binoche with Japanese actors for racial equality, but you don't

is this movie should take place solely in Japan and remove the notion that

same fate as those from the first nuclear bombings in WWII? That makes it 
seem like you think that because it didn't happen to us we don't have to 
worry or care about it. That is completely untrue and insensitive to all 
other countries. This movie could give American audiences an opportunity to 
have a better understanding of the catastrophe that took place in Japan

The 1954 Godzilla, of course, was a symbol of nuclear holocaust. The

World War 2.

The 2014 Godzilla, is a Symbol of how nature cannot be controlled by man, 
and ultimately how much more powerful it can be than humanity and how 
uncontrollable it actually is.

For this movie, you're blowing the racial aspect way out of proportion and

let them decide by themselves if race is an issue in this movie or not.﻿

They reason why comic con placed Godzilla in Japan is because they want to

will be in Japan in one act of the movie, then to Hawaii and San Fransisco.

of Godzilla, and hopefully the movie explains why he goes from point A 
(Japan) to point B (San Fransisco). I understand the whole racial aspect, 
but who is there to say that there won't be any in the movie. An original 
cast member of the original 1954 Gojira film, Akira Takarada, is going to 
plan an unknown role in the film. The reason why everyone is ok with 
changing the racial ethnicity is because since it is an American film, it 
is expected to show less, I repeat less Japanese characters because it 
mostly takes place in America. However, we won't know if there won't be any 
Japanese or Asian characters. Now, speaking of characters, lest be honest.

the military or nuclear scientist? When we see the film we'll follow a more 
interesting set of characters because the military and scientist add to the 
dynamic of the film, and obviously the film will show the effect of 
encountering such a monster. Even though they're soldiers and scientist, 
they are still human. The 1998 film is NOT Godzilla. That creature did not 
have the characteristics of the original Godzilla, and the story was not 
remotely good or did justice to the original film. The 1998 film lacked 
characters that we wanted to care about. In the 2014 film, they will do 
justice to the original film and have characters that we should care about,

a true die hard fan does Not want a 1998 Godzilla film.﻿

Hollywood today. And almost to ridiculous lengths, like "The Last 
Airbender" or Tonto from "The Lone Ranger"; ironically a role that has been 
almost always been played by 'First Nation' actors. Especially in the even 
far more 'white-washed' Hollywood past.

And a wider variety of characters, gender and racial wise, would be a much 
need change of paste, from what we keep getting. Including, as you 
mentioned above, the constant re-casting of characters and EVEN real-life 
historical figures who are anything BUT Caucasians.

On the other-hand, considering how the normal American movie-going public 
has such stereotypical, possibly even 'slightly racist' assumptions on the 
Godzilla franchise (and Japanese entertainment in general), having the new 
Godzilla picking on (and outright killing) mostly Caucasian characters, 
might drive home the point that the character of Godzilla is a universal 
threat against ALL of humanity (hairless monkey beasts the Earth over), 
instead of just Japan and its local territories.

A significant story point, and dramatic theme, that the Japanese film 
makers and creators of the original 1954 "Godzilla" 
("Gojira"...tamato...tomato), very much had in mind, with the Anti-War 
message conveyed in that film. That, along with the simple thrill of seeing 
a giant monster wreaking whole cities with its bare claws, on the big 
screen!﻿

This is all 52 flavors of wrong! First off, we're not calling for an all

not, but just from the trailer, I can tell this movie is paying so much 
more attention to the origins of Godzilla than the 98 version could ever

better than the 98. It starts in Japan, stays in the Pacific, Godzilla was 
born in 1954, and is a nuclear dinosaur instead of a... weird 
raptor-iguana. And also, really fun fact, the 1998 monster is now legally 
called (I'm not joking, look it up) Zilla. So the film may be called

And this movie isn't a remake, it's a reboot. Very different terms there. A 
remake is when it's supposed to be the same movie, but "updated." A reboot, 
which this is, is when there's an original plot, contains the same 
concept/character (Godzilla) but is new.

Well to be fair, the original Godzilla is allegory for nuclear disaster and 
the deaths of hundreds of thousands of people in Japan during 1945, which 
definitely *is* something to be taken seriously. Godzilla was never 
intended to be a traditional 'monster' nor the movie a 'monster movie'. It 
was a human drama about ignorance versus unstoppable forces of nature.

On topic: I do not think race is important. I think the Japanese film is 
intrinsically going to have a Japanese cast, nobody complained that the 
original film had no caucasian characters. Godzilla, while containing a 
cultural significance, it was made to stand against mankind as a whole, 
having decided to use nuclear weapons and so on.

Okay, I'm actually half-Japanese and half-English (not really one of the 
"hardcore Godzilla fans", but I've seen my fair share). Being someone who 
has seen how popular and fundamentally defining it is in Japan, I think 
it's a shame that the movie itself is trying to move away from that 
community. Personally, there appears to be nothing wrong with the story 
expanding from its origin, it's probably necessary nowadays. But is it too 
hard to head hunt a Japanese actor/actress, hell maybe even an Asian one if 
it's too hard. I acknowledge that there is a language barrier, so obviously 
there would not be much choice for a Japanese lead. However, I think to be 
respectful to the source material and those in Japan who have been brought 
up with this franchise from a much earlier age than many of the westerners, 
it would only be right to give a little more respect to that Japanese side, 
even if only a little more.﻿

I just want to say that I am fans of Aaron Taylor-Johnson and Elizabeth

I do see your point, Grace. Some people are commenting to not focus on 
race, but I do get what you're trying to say. It is kind of offensive that 
films that originate from other countries are being 'Americanized'. I 
believe that certain films should stay true to their culture instead of 
following what Hollywood does all the time and they would stand out more if 
that's what they did. But the sad truth is that they don't. We fall into 
these stereotypes about certain cultures and we all know that's never 
really the case. I think we all have these double standards as you 
mentioned with changing Johnny Storm (I personally just like Chris Evans in 
that role), but I do feel it's unfair to say 'oh, we can change this and 
everyone will love it' but to be too afraid to change something else 
because maybe people won't love it. As much as I enjoy a good film, I do 
believe that films should stay true to their culture and they would still 
be great films if executed correctly. But- When I go see Godzilla, will I 
be sitting there saying that because it's not authentic that I can't enjoy 
it? No. I will create my opinion on Godzilla based on what is portrayed on

actually did not mean for this comment to be so long.)﻿

Again, Hollywood already judged based on race. They're usually scared to 
hire unknown non-white actors in lead roles, because they think that movies 
about non-white people are not successful enough.

Like with Redtails, which Hollywood refused to fund because it was supposed 
to be an expensive film with an entirely black cast (they said that movies 
about black people don't make enough money, and that black people arent 
"marketable" enough)

Or with Wong Fu Productions, whos movie was cancelled because they wanted 
their lead actor to be Asian (Hollywood told them that Asians aren't 
profitable enough, and the movies need white actors in order to make money)

Or with "Better Luck" Tomorrow, which Hollywood refused to fund because it 
had an entirely Asian cast,

Or with "Tokyo Drift," in which the director wanted a lead Asian actor, but 
Hollywood studios didn't want him to do that. They wanted him to hire a 
caucasian actor instead, and so the director had to fight to have 
colorblind casting call for his lead characters,

Or with Anansi Boys, a fantasy book in which all of the characters were 
black, but Hollywood refused to consider black actors for the live action 
movie because they said that "of course the characters won't be black in 
the movie because black people don't like fantasy,"

So race matters in Hollywood. It shouldn't, because actors should be chosen 
based on talent, rather than race. This doesn't mean Godzilla is a bad 
movie, it just means that Hollywood judges on race.

Dear Grace,

I am a fan of your site and admire the way you dissect movies. On the 
issues you raised on the upcoming Godzilla movie, I totally agree with the 
points you raised. I am from Malaysia where we get an equal dose of both 
Asian,American,Indian and other region movies here, being a potpourri of 
multiple cultures.

With regards to Japanese movies, we tend to watch them in Japanese with 
English subtitles even though many cannot understand the language just to 
experience the full effect of the movie as intended..This is also the norm 
for all other movies of different languages.

When you make movies such as these where the source material originates

Grace, the film is not being sold to take place in Japan. If this were so, 
I'm sure the majority would have similar concerns which isn't the case. 
Most of the footage shown looks like it take place in the US, specifically 
in San Francisco and Las Vegas.

I see where you're coming from with the cultural argument, but it's more 
important for stories like Akira because the culture is so significant to 
the story that it couldn't properly work if set in America. Godzilla may 
have carried a lot of symbolism of Japan's past once, but not so much now 
as later films primarily portrayed him simply as a destructive kaiju that 
defended and attacked the world. I just don't feel the attachment is as 
strong as you suggest.

Also, why follow a group of Hawaiian kids who will not be relevant 
throughout the story, especially since they will essentially be limited to 
only one part of the film? Why follow a character in China Town just 
because they're Asian? Does their race suddenly make them relevant to the 
story? I feel this decision would only lose focus since Godzilla will be a 
global threat this time. Sure it'd be nice to have Cranston's character 
replaced with someone who was Japanese, but Cranston is also the most 
marketable actor in the entire film and clearly grabbed the director's 
attention with his screen test. Race shouldn't determine a role, the acting 
and story should.

I mentioned this on in your previous review, but I don't remember a lot of 
people being upset over Johnny Storm's race change. I remember people 
primarily being upset over the possibility that Johnny wouldn't be Sue's 
brother, which is more crucial to the character than race. Concern over 
relationships of characters is actually important to the story.

I personally don't mind if another culture remakes something that was 
originally made in the US, and it's not like the majority of Godzilla films 
from Japan are concerned with race. While I love The Raid, I have too admit 
some great remakes have from adapting foreign films, such as The Departed. 
I don't have a problem with The Raid. I just doubt it'll be as well made as 
the original or offer a unique perspective on the subject. 

I'll conclude this by saying I agree it would benefit everyone to encourage 
a blend of different cultures in a film and to expose themselves to the 
original film. That being said, I don't feel there is anything wrong in 
seeing one cultures interpretation of a theme or concept. Saying that 
Godzilla can only be viewed through a lens that is strictly Japanese. We 
say this annoys us here in the US, but again it happens everywhere else 
when they decide to adapt something made in the US. The difference is 
Hollywood has the burden of being popular, and therefore is more exposed 
and pressured to represent everyone even if it does nothing to actual story 
being told.

This was a great topic of discussion and I'm glad you addressed this topic 
in a full video. While I may not entirely agree with you I do feel this 
discussion is valuable. Thank you.﻿

"Race shouldn't determine a role, the acting and story should."
The problem with this is that race already plays a big part in Hollywood. 
You're talking about it an idealized way- as if racism no longer exists in 
Hollywood.
It's like this... Hollywood producers need to make money, and they think 
that movies about non-white people do not make enough money. Hollywood 
wants directors and actors they can make $$ off of, it's not just about 
talent or quality (otherwise, why is Megan Fox still relevant?)

They want lead actors who draw in large audiences, and they think that 
non-white actors make viewers disinterested (unless said actor is somebody 
like Will Smith or Samuel L. Jackson, Hollywood's favorite token black 
actors). So they usually refused to fund or greenlight films about 
non-white characters.

Examples being (since people never believe me):
-"Redtails," which Hollywood refused to fund because of its all black cast 
(they said "black people aren't marketable enough"). So the director, 
George Lucas, used money out of his own pocket to cover production costs on 
the film ($58m). The movie bombed, and Hollywood blamed it on the fact that 
the movie had an all black cast, rather than the poor directing. And so now 
they are afraid to make high budget "black films."
-"A Moment With You," which was cancelled because the directors (Wong Fu 
Productions) wanted an Asian lead actors. Hollywood producers told them 
that Asians "arent profitable enough," and that movies need white actors in 
order to make money.
-"Anansi Boys," a fantasy story influenced by west African folklore. 
Hollywood wanted to make a movie of it, but told the author "the characters 
can't be black in the movie because black people don't like fantasy."
-"Tokyo Drift," in which the director had to fight to have a colorblind 
auditions for the lead characters. He wanted to chose an Asian actor, but 
the studio he was working with was bent on having a white actor, and so 
they got their way.
-Mako was turned down by Hollywood executives when he wanted to make a TV 
show about an Asian protagonist, because Hollywood executives told him that 
"viewers would shut off the TV if they seen an Asian protagonist."

So yeah. Movies SHOULDN'T be about race, but race still plays a big part in 
which projects Hollywood choses to greenlight.

Well if it gives you some relief as a fan, the creators of the movie are 
long time fans of the original Toho Godzilla, and they have a Toho director 
acting as the adviser and producer for the film. In addition, Toho has been 
in the loop through the entire process and is being much more careful than 
in 1998.
-
In fact one of the major reasons the new film takes place where it does and 
casts who it did was because of Toho. Originally the agreed upon script had 
Japanese and Japanese American actors and took place in Japan. The new film 
has been in production for a very long time, in time for the tsunami and 
nuclear incident to occur. A tidal wave and nuclear plant meltdown also 
happen in the movie. Toho and Legendary thought it would be disrespectful 
to the families to have tusnamis and nuclear meltdowns associated with 
Japan and the Japanese people. So the story was shifted to the US and the 
casting was made with the full approval by Toho

+Grace Randolph +Beyond The Trailer Haha, this is going to be a long one 

 I have only seen the original Japanese Godzilla (which I love) and the 
1998 Emmerich version (which I hate), it's also important to note that I'm 
a big fan of Japanese/Asian cinema and anime. I knew that the film did 
mainly take place in America, but I thought Japan and Japanese people would 
play a major role. I am disappointed to see that Japan doesn't feature as 
much as I thought it did, but at least they seem to acknowledge japan to an 
extent, albeit a limited one. I don't think it looks like the piece of crap 
Emmerich version. That movie didn't have a lot going for it. It had down 
right stupid scenes and dumb comedy. Overall it just felt like a chesy 
special effects 90s movie with a big lizard, not Godzilla. This movie looks 
alot more serious, and captures the horror movie like tone of the original- 
what would actually happen if Godzilla attacked. The beast in this IS 
Godzilla and not a big lizard and the characters seem to have more depth 
then the 1998 version. I still think the film, visually is artistic and has 
a memorable look and style to it, again the 1998 version felt generic and 
cheesy, like and extended version of the last part of Jurassic park 2. 

In terms of a Japanese setting, whilst I am disappointed it doesn't feature 
as much as I thought, I do like how they're going for a global feel here 
and I think that makes sense in terms of a realistic Godzilla movie. As for 
cast, yes we do need more asian cast members in general, but if i had to 
choose between an asian cast and Bryan cranston, I'd pick Cranston. Also, 
and I might be wrong here, if Legendary is trying to make a movie that goes 
down well in china, casting it Japanese heavy might not be a good idea as 
Chinese people don't seem to like Japanese people. But having a multiple 
Chinese characters in this film would seem culturally insensitive towards 
Japan. What do you think about this idea Grace ? Overall though yes i would 
like a more Japanese focused film but at least they acknowledge it to an 
extent, which is better then most films. 

In terms of how this differs from the the two cases you mentioned, Michael 
B Jordan in FF and The Raid remake, well it's different in each case. I 
think that downplaying the Japanese element in this film is disappointing 
because Godzilla is not only Japans most famous export (arguable :p) but 
Japanese culture is kinda entrenched in the Godzilla mythos, that whole 
post nuclear war effects/destructive power of nature when messed with 
theme, this is also prevalent in other Japanese movies like Akira. On the 
other hand i think MBJ in FF is a brilliant as a) we need more black 
superheroes b) being white isn't integral to the character c) You can be 
American and Black, as their isnt a race connected with america other then 
native americans d) it updates it, as there are alot of black people in 
america so a black hero in a team up film makes sense and e) FF isn't 
exactly a famous american export, you guys have so many exports ! As for 
the Raid remake, i think it's alot worse. People recognise that Godzilla is 
a Japanese creation, and Japan has a healthy film industry. Indonesia does 
not, and people will not recognise that the Raid is of Indonesian origin, 
(though the film was made by a fellow welshman :D). The film has done alot 
to bring Indonesia up on the international film stage, so in that way the 
raid is quite a special film. That why it would be a big shame to see that 
trampled on.

I've often said that, if I were a video game developer, the last thing I 
would ever do would be to make a game starring a female protagonist, 
because virtually every game that stars a female protagonist is accused of 
being sexist. Why would I want to deal with the headache of being accused 
of being a sexist for just making a video game, when I can avoid that by 
simply making the game focus on a male protagonist? This is why I've always 
felt that the people who constantly accuse female video game characters of 
being sexist are doing themselves a disservice, because they're also 
usually the same people who complain that there aren't enough female 
protagonists in video games, and all they're doing is making game 
developers more reluctant to use female characters out of fear of being 
labelled a sexist.

I hadn't really thought about this until now, but this probably applies to 
other forms of art and entertainment as well. If I were making a movie, I'd 
be reluctant to make the movie focus on anyone other than white Americans 
living in America, because I wouldn't want to attempt portraying someone 
else's culture and have to deal with being called a racist because I got 
something wrong or made an innocent mistake. People tend to not like it 
when people of other ethnic or cultural backgrounds try to portray their 
own culture in art or entertainment. Not too long ago I read a story about 
Katy Perry being accused of racism because she did a performance that had a 
Japanese theme, but part of her outfit was Chinese apparently. Also, some 
complained that the entire performance was out of line, because they felt 
that it was disrespectful for a "white privileged" performer to portray 
Japanese culture in one of her performances. Another example is a recent 
episode of How I Met Your Mother where they did a parody of old Japanese 
Kung Fu movies. Some people found the episode offensive and the creators 
had to issue an apology.

Who the hell would want to deal with that? I know I wouldn't. So I can't 
blame anyone else for not wanting to deal with it. I don't think it would 
be worth the headache for them to try to make this Godzilla movie focus on 
Japanese culture or Japanese characters. If you're going to(and I don't 
mean you, Grace, but people in general) cry racism, or sexism, or 
whatever-ism every single time someone tries to portray your race, gender, 
or culture in art or entertainment, then don't be surprised when fewer 
people are interested in portraying your race, gender, or culture in art or 
entertainment.

I personally didn't have a problem with them changing Johnny Storm's race,

they're supposed to be brother and sister. The fact that they only changed

being said, I think the reason why a lot of other people had a problem with 
them changing Johnny Storm's race, but not changing the race of the 
characters of Godzilla is simple. The Fantastic 4 is the focus of the 
Fantastic 4 movies. They're the ones people want to see, and so naturally 
people are going to be more protective of those characters. Where as the 
focus of Godzilla is Godzilla. The human characters are an after thought. 
As long as Godzilla looks the way people think he should, most people 
aren't going to care what the human characters look like. This is why I 
think that this change isn't a big deal. Even Asian Godzilla fans are going 
to watch a Godzilla movie to see Godzilla. So I don't think they're going 
to care too much about the setting or the race of the people Godzilla is 
trying to step on.﻿

I fail to see how white people being experts in a Japanese nuclear plant is 
all that odd/stereotypical/elitist...if you look in history, even the 
states during WWII recruited Russian and German nuclear scientists and the 
rise of the nuclear industry globally brought 
physicists/engineers/scientists from all over the world to travel abroad to 
be "experts" at nuclear facilities. What about Tesla? He immigrated from 
the Austria and he was an expert albeit working under Thomas Edison for a 
while, he was Caucasian as well. 
   Now, a majority of average viewers who saw the first teaser trailer knew 
that the location of the HALO jump was in San Francisco, so I don't 
understand how it could be misinterpreted as being a pure Japanese location 
film. Like you've already pointed out, you're now aware that the film takes 
place in a few locations and I'd like to point out that the team in charge 
of creating the movie has said, "we wanted the film to feel like a global 
threat, that this can happen anywhere and everywhere", I'm paraphrasing of 
course, but that is very close to what was said. I don't really think that 
the advertising was necessarily "misleading" as the comic con experience 
and official posters could be considered the origin of Godzilla as well as 
an easy way to parallel the new movie to the old, sounds like they did a 
good job of "pulling from the source material." 
   As for how much other races will be playing a role in the film, we've 
only seen short glimpses and trailers, so I don't understand how you can 
make the assumption that the film won't showcase the citizens of Japan, 
Hawaii, etc., at the same time, I'd think it'd be MORE stereotypical and 
cliche to highlight specifically the Asian cultures in scenes of everyday 
life or running away from where Caucasian people tend to flock. I would 
think it'd make people sigh and think, "wow...really? filming a ton of 
Asians running away from Chinatown? As if we weren't aware of that culture 
already." It'd be better just to show a ton of mixed people intermingling 
and running in fear than to highlight one specific race, which Legendary 
hasn't done in the trailers, they've shown both citizens and tourists of 
all races. As for Ken Watanabe's role in the film, the average viewer may 
not assume that he has a huge role based on the trailer, but anyone who has 
been following the Godzilla viral marketing or goes on forums knows 
otherwise. There are files on him on the mutoresearch website, there's 
input codes regarding his name, pictures, files, etc. so I highly doubt 
that his role is just a shout out and his role is small. 
   To address the source material and how Toho signed off on all of this, 
this movie pulls HEAVILY from the source material, from Gareth saying there 
will be easter eggs in the film that pays homage to the original Godzilla 
films to the reference of a 1954 attack/situation. Also, this movie 
highlights and tributes the original message Godzilla originally had..that 
nuclear power/the arrogance of man is the downfall of us, that we toy with 
nature as if it's in our control, I'd say that is pulling from the source 
material. I'd also like to point out my own theory that the original 
Godzilla film from 1954 was to bring about the message of nuclear energy 
and at the time the film didn't really highlight it as a global event, 
Gareth is modernizing this message and building upon it to make it 
realistic, like I pointed out earlier, that disaster can happen anywhere, 
it can be a global event...again, pulling from the source material, all 
this probably being a good reason as to why Toho signed off on all this, 
because it ISN'T another American Godzilla, it's a very Original homage to 
the Japanese Godzilla. 
  This is pretty much what I have to say, it's lengthy, but it's from 
someone's point of view who is genuinely interested in the film and doesn't 
see race being an issue as race doesn't even seem to be an issue..possibly 
because I've done my research and not because I'm programmed to think only 
Caucasian people can be in American films. ﻿

This took me a long ass time to write, so I hope it's not wasted.

Okay. The first two big parts of the film take place in Japan. Probably a 
good twenty minutes worth of movie is in Japan. For the most part, the 
movie takes place with the monster as it makes it's way to the city of San 
Francisco. The reason why they aren't staying in Japan is because the 
director, along with pretty much everyone working on the film, believe that 
something like this would be a global thing, not just limited to a monster 
bash in Tokyo. If a giant creature, capable of getting around the globe 
easily, has been "awakened" for more than 60 years, do you honestly think 
that it would just stick around Japan? I don't think that it would. An 
interview with Patrick Sabongui revealed that these creatures are a global 
thing, and that they can get around pretty fast. Not to mention that the 
San Francisco scenes have been quite obvious. You've got the Golden Gate 
Bridge, you've got posters, you've got the trailers practically shoving San 
Francisco setting down your throat.

There is another Asian actor in the movie. His role has been kept under 
wraps though. It's one of the best kept secrets about this movie.

If you noticed that the movie starts off in Japan, and ends in the United 
States. It's sort of what the intention was. It was sort of a thing that 
visually shows Godzilla's journey to the United States (from Toho to 
Legendary; Japan to the States). Interesting? I think so.

The Brody's, the family that is (or was) made up of the characters 
portrayed by Bryan Cranston, Juliette Binoche, and Aaron Taylor Johnson, 
live in Japan. They aren't just there because Japan had a problem with 
their nuclear reactors and they're brought in. A lot of the viral marketing 
suggests that Cranston and Binoche's characters just happen to work at the 
Janjira plant and are good at what they do. Just because they're white 
people in Japan, doesn't mean that they're just there because they're 
experts or tourists. There are white people that live in Japan. Cranston 
and Binoche are probably just people that are good at what they do. You 
kind of have to be an expert to work at a nuclear power plant. It's not 
like it's a summer job for a fourteen year old looking to make an extra 
buck.

And not to come across as rude, but saying that people who have been 
following this movie very closely since before it was going to be an 
American movie, (2007ish is when Yoshimitsu Banno acquired the rights to 
make a 40 minute sequel to his movie Godzilla vs Hedorah (or Godzilla vs 
The Smog Monster) is a bit insulting to those that have invested quite a 
bit of time into following the movie. The reason why the movie seems to be 
following white people is because the movie is centered around Aaron Taylor 
Johnson's character, Ford Brody, who is an EOD specialist in the Navy while 
he tries to bring his family back together.  Aaron Taylor Johnson is white. 
Has Aaron Taylor Johnson been marketed much? No. For the very same reason 
that Ken Watanabe hasn't. The marketing team feels that Bryan Cranston is 
going to be the one to steal the show. Even with Johnson being the lead 
actor, everyone feels that Cranston is going to steal the show anyways.

And not to sound horrible, but how many asian-american actors are actually 
in demand (actual question, as it doesn't seem like many are) that aren't 
already committed to a project?

Godzilla was never about Japan. In all seriousness, Godzilla was never 
about Japan. It doesn't matter where Godzilla attacks, what the monster is 
doing. The one thing that Godzilla was about was the idea of nuclear 
holocaust (at least in the more serious movies). I think that's why a lot 
of people don't care about the whole race thing. It's not because it's what 
we want, it's because we know that the ethnicity of the people are 
completely irrelevant to what the monster itself stands for. The reason 
people were upset over the change of Johnny Storm's race change (as far as 
I'm aware of) is because Sue Storm wasn't changed as well. They're blood 
siblings, why wouldn't they be the same race?

And the thing about Godzilla's characters... They're rarely the same from 
movie to movie. One movie could be following a young reporter that helps a 
scientist lure Godzilla into a volcano and the next one be about a trio 
consisting of a soldier, scientist, and some chick with plot convenient ESP 
as they try to make up their minds about how to kill Godzilla. The 
characters are rarely consistent from film to film. All of the characters 
in the movies are hard to care about. The only human character worth 
mentioning is Daisuke Serizawa, the man who killed Godzilla in the first 
movie with his brand new invention that he was forced to weaponize. 
Everyone else is pretty much Guy With Camera, Guy With Annoying Voice, Girl 
With Convenient Powers, Annoying Kid #1, Annoying Kid #2, Running Woman 
#764, Kid Who Keeps Tripping, Kumi Mitzuno, Alien Douchebag, Annoying 
Business Man, Guy Who Was Blasted Away By Godzilla, Man Who Kidnapped the 
Twin Fairies... etc. These people have names that are easy to forget. 
Nobody cares about the human characters in Toho's movies for the most part. 
I'm sure that someone here can easily list off all of the names of the 
monsters though. And the monsters are not Japanese, they're animals and 
creatures that fight with other creatures.﻿

Appreciate what you do, but there's some glaring issues I have. Toho has 
sought an American made Godzilla movie for quite some time now. They were 
very dissapointed with the 1998 film. So much so that they fought in court 
to have the name Godzilla removed from the Kaiju used in the 1998 film. 
Yes, the film is still called Godzilla, but the monster in that film no 
longer carries that name.

After Gareth Edwards made the movie "Monsters" (a fantastic film imo that 
has great commentary on the silly xenophobia people have towards immigrants 
and immigration in general) in 2010, Toho approached an American movie 
company once again to make a yet another Godzilla remake. They wanted 
Edwards (a British director btw) to direct/helm the film and keep it as 
close as possible to the original Godzilla as possible. While also 
appealing to a wider and younger audiance.

If anything, this is a more true and fair remake than the American edit 
released in 1955. The one with Raymond Burr. Those who speak of the 
"Original Godzilla" are often thinking of that version of the film, not 
knowing that it dramatically altered the original. References to the 
bombings of Nagasaki and Hiroshima are removed. Irradiated drinking wells 
are instead simply "contaminated". Footage of the aftermath of the atomic 
bombings are removed, as is footage of the crew of the Daigo Fukuryu Maru 
fishing boat that was irradiated by H bomb testing. In the 1954 original, 
Godzilla is simply awoken from sleep by atomic testing in the Pacific, 
irradiated by it, and unable to return to his "under water cavern" home 
because of it. Not mutated by it as in the 1955 edit.

In the original, Godzilla was an anti-hero. With radiation burns covering 
his entire body, he rampaged acrossed a city and killed thousands. Not 
because he was a mean monster (as in the 1955 American edit) but because he 
was hurt, scared, and frankly...had been on this planet long before any of 
us. Who were we to build our cities on his home? He was sympathetic. Which 
is why when Dr. Serizawa killed Godzilla with the Oxygen Destroyer, it was 
more sad than joyous. (It is worth mentioning that Dr Serizawa is in the 
2014 film, and to be played by Ken Watanabe.)

Gareth Edwards has said, he wants Godzilla to be an anti-hero in this film. 
Not a mean, destroy everything monster. That, in of itself, makes this a 
worthy adaptation of the 1954 original.

Is it odd that this film doesn't take place only in Japan? Yes, maybe a 
bit. Is it racist that not all of the main characters are Japanese? I 
suppose it could be interpreted that way. It saddens me that it is being 
done so by some. Godzilla transcends race and creed at this point. He's a 
worldwide phenomenon that appeals to more than just Japan. As a 4 year old 
boy, I was able to relate to the people of Japan and the monster itself 
even though they were Japanese.

The original message of the film (Godzilla being a metaphore for the atomic 
bomb) is not entirely lost on today's public, but it doesn't carry the same 
weight that it once did. Not even in Japan. Part of that is Toho's fault 
for gearing Godzilla more towards children as it went on. It is my hope, as 
a Godzilla fan, that this adaptation captures some of that original 
magic/message. Nature is beyond our control, and will not be tamed. As a 
functioning G-fan (I get out of my mom's basement from time to time ;) jk) 
I then submit that this film will, at the very least, be a better and more 
worthy adaptation/remake than the 1955 American edit or the 1998 debacle.

I hope you took the time to read my rant and again I appreciate your work. 
Much love and good luck to you.

encountering Godzilla. That was the idea from the start, and I'm pretty 
sure that sign usually points to white people being in the lead role. But 
why has such a sudden stink been created over this? Because some person 
with many followers online wrongfully assumed the setting of the movie and 
went and played the race/whitewashing card in a move of sheer ignorance.

becoming minorities in some major areas across the country. But should a 
movie really be taking a beating all of a sudden because someone didn't do 
any research whatsoever before posting a video online? And decided to do 
some race baiting?
